title: Why Biggest is Rarely Best in Real Estate
text:
In Dallas, it’s a French chateau with space for 10 living rooms and a padded gymnasium; in Rolling Rock, California, it’s a red-roofed Mediteranean villa custom built with 25 bathrooms; and in Rancho Santa Fe, outside San Diego, California, it’s an airy modern new construction with glass walls and a dedicated master wing.



The three mansions of vastly different styles and locations share a common status as “the largest house in town,” clocking in at four-to-five times the size of the median home in their posh neighborhoods. They also happen to share the misfortune of having sat at some point on the market unsold for years.



They are just a few of the many examples that show that, when it comes to smart real estate investment, biggest is rarely best. Those who build or buy homes exponentially larger than their neighbors often face an equally large job when it comes time to sell, including prolonged listing times, numerous discounts and the potential for a negative return on investment. That’s because such disproportionate homes have a limited appeal even among buyers with infinite resources, who often consider qualities beyond sheer size.



More: Ultra-Modern London Mansion With Pool and Tennis Court Asks £40 Million

Returns Diminish



“There are diminishing returns on size,” said Jonathan Miller, a New York-based real estate appraiser. “Just by adding square footage doesn’t mean that it contributes proportionally to value.”



Mr. Miller offered the example of a 30,000-square-foot mansion built in an area where the typical home is more like 10,000 square feet. “It doesn’t mean that the value is going to be triple its neighbors. It would likely be worth more, but not proportionally,” he said.



A recent example of the diminishing returns on size is The Manor, a Los Angeles estate built in the early 1990s by TV producer Aaron Spelling, and at 56,500 square feet—roughly the size of a football field—it’s one of the, if not the, largest completed house in the city.



The Manor set a record for Los Angeles County in July when it traded hands for nearly $120 million, Mansion Global reported at the time. And while it was the highest overall price, the value of each square foot, at $1,120, was fairly low for an L.A. trophy home. For instance, the Playboy Mansion just down the street sold for a whopping $5,000 per square foot when it traded hands for $100 million in 2016.



The Manor in Holmby Hills, Los Angeles Getty Images

“Larger houses can have a lower price per foot when you get past a certain size,” Mr. Miller said.



Even the two-bedroom 1930s house across the street sold nine years ago for 30% more than the Manor on a square-foot basis, property records show.



“You never want to be the most expensive house in any community, whether that be the tract, subdivision or city neighborhood—that’s theoretically,” said Jeffrey Hyland, president at Hilton & Hyland and one of the brokers on the Manor and Playboy Mansion. “The reality is there’s always a buyer for the best property, especially in L.A. where you are in some ways expected to show off your success.”



But when it comes to the most elite trophy homes, details—including the view, architect and provenance of a house—can create far more value than simply size, he said.



“A lot of developers believe that the more square footage, the more you would get and that’s absolutely not true,” he said. “If the smaller house next door has a better view, it probably commands a higher price.”



More: Los Angeles Prices Hit New High Amid Sliding Transactions

Square footage played barely a supporting role in the sale of Malibu’s record breaker, a teak-clad beach house hotelier Peter Morton sold last year for $110 million. The relatively modest-sized home on billionaire-favored Carbon Beach spans less than 7,000 square feet, but shattered the area’s price record due to its location on 100 feet of prime beach and its star architectural pedigree, said Mr. Hyland, also a broker on the sale.



“It was all about architecture, it was all about location,” he said, adding that other sometimes overlooked factors include a property’s acreage, privacy and security.



Reselling Requires Patience, Often Price Cuts



For those who venture ahead with building or buying the biggest house in town, be warned it will likely take a long time to sell and go through multiple price cuts, history shows.



NBA legend Shaquille O’Neal is well acquainted with the challenge of selling the biggest house for miles. His palatial Mediteranean-style home outside Orlando, Florida, is so big it’s hosted whole professional basketball teams to practice in its 6,000-square-foot regulation-size basketball court. Shaq’s taken the home on and off the market since since May 2018 and slashed one-fifth off its original $28 million asking price, Mansion Global previously reported.



Dustin Fealy, a listing agent with The Agency Collective in Florida, told Mansion Global when it last relisted in June that Mr. O’Neal managed somehow to make it homey despite its massive size. “A lot of megamansions over 30,000 square feet have the feeling of an office building,” he said at the time.



More: With a $40 Million Price Cut, Spelling Manor Still Among L.A.’s Most Expensive Homes

That’s all to say nothing of the massive upkeep that goes into maintaining a palatial house, which could put off any buyer.



Take the largest privately owned home in England, Wentworth Woodhouse, an 18th-century manor that boasts five miles of corridors and so many rooms no one knows exactly how many there are. Even with its historic cache—it’s said to be the inspiration for Pemberley Estate in Jane Austen’s “Pride and Prejudice”—the estate ultimately sold after three years on the market to preservationists for £7 million, Mansion Global reported at the time.



The Wentworth Woodhouse estate in South Yorkshire Wikipedia

But it doesn’t have to be palatial for size to present an issue when it comes time to sell, as Alexandra Sierra of Compass Florida knows well. She’s marketing a custom-built hurricane-proofed home on the border of Miami suburbs Coral Gables and Coconut Grove, and at nearly 5,500 square feet has struggled to sell because it’s larger and more modernized than anything in the neighborhood.



“The square footage is killing me,” she said of the five-bedroom house asking $2.5 million.



From Penta: The Lamborghini 2020 Huracan Evo Spyder Packs A Lot of Punch in a Little Package

Palatial home owners and developers may also face trouble selling in the future as younger millionaires have shown a greater preference for smaller but better built and better amenitized homes, Ms. Sierra said.



“Millennials who buy houses between $2 million and $4 million want functionality. It’s very rare that you see them buying mansions where you have to take care of huge lawns and enormous houses,” Ms. Sierra said. “They want simple, they want smaller square footage and they’re thinking about how the floor plan flows.”



She added: “It’s going to make these megamansions obsolete.”
